awd_titl_txt: Supplemental Instruction with Mindset Training in STEM Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
To improve student persistence in STEM majors, this project at Illinois College will adapt, implement, and enhance a model of supplemental instruction that was designed at California State Fullerton (NSF Award 1432829).  The enhanced supplemental instruction model will include training to help students develop a growth mindset, which includes the perspective that effort can overcome academic difficulties.  Advanced undergraduate students will be trained as supplemental instruction leaders and will work under faculty mentors to lead mindset training activities in science and math classes. It is expected that mindset training will help students develop learning skills that they can transfer from introductory to advanced courses, thereby increasing their academic confidence and success.  If successful in achieving its goals, this project's combination of supplemental instruction and mindset training may be applicable to any undergraduate STEM course. 
 
The goal of this project is to determine whether the integration of peer supplemental instruction with mindset training activities (derived from research on student growth mindset, non-cognitive skills, and "grit") will improve learning outcomes and persistence of students in undergraduate STEM courses. The supplemental instruction activities will complement classroom and laboratory activities in both gateway and upper-level courses.  The project goals are to increase students' awareness of their learning experiences and to help them embrace the inherent challenge of learning, which is expected to translate improved learning outcomes for students and for supplemental instruction student leaders. Project objectives include: (1) determining the effectiveness of a supplemental instruction model for STEM courses that integrates Enhanced Mindset Instruction; (2) developing metacognition, self-efficacy, and growth mindset of supplemental instruction student leaders' so they can facilitate STEM students' persistence to STEM degree completion; and (3) developing metacognition, self-efficacy, and growth mindset of STEM students, to increase their persistence to STEM degree completion. Results of project assessment and evaluation will add to the body of knowledge about effective practices for student learning, especially in STEM courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To address the issue of retention in STEM majors at a small liberal arts college, the project "Students Teaching with Enhanced Mindsets in STEM" involved determining the effectiveness of an integrated peer Supplemental Instruction (SI) model for target gateway STEM courses: Precalculus, Calculus I , Molecular Genetics, General Chemistry, Organic Chemistry I & II, and College Physics I & II (Fig. 2). Faculty and peer SI facilitators were trained in enhanced mindset and metacognitive instruction with the goal of increasing STEM student and peer SI academic content knowledge. The project also aimed to develop target course students' metacognition, self-efficacy, and growth mindset through course-specific activities during weekly SI sessions. (Fig. 1)

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts:

During a three-day workshop prior to the start of each semester, instructors and peer SI(s) for target courses were trained in best practices for supplemental instruction in STEM, understanding the role of growth mindset in student success, and understanding the role of metacognition in student self-efficacy. Instructors and peer SI(s) developed frameworks for planning SI sessions that incorporated effective disciplinary-specific pedagogy and integrated mindset and metacognitive elements.

Experiences in optimizing the training course curriculum allowed for dissemination to our own SI training programs across all disciplines at the college, showing that the integration of mindset and metacognition instruction in SI sessions has implications for student success beyond STEM disciplines. In terms of dissemination to other institutions with STEM peer SI or similar programs, the results of our project were shared at a 2022 AAAS IUSE Summit on Propelling Change. The framework and suggestions for implementation were shared in a 2022 workshop at the AAC&U Transforming STEM Higher Education Conference. 

Summary of Outcomes:

Statistical models from the final semester of implementation showed that growth in mindset was a significant predictor of students' content gains scores, such that students with larger gains on the growth mindset measure showed statistically significantly larger gains on their content scores (Fig. 3). Results from student surveys across all semesters and all courses were consistent and showed that students considered SI sessions to be at least somewhat useful (Fig. 4) for: reflecting on course content, understanding and developing study techniques, impacting their growth mindset, and helping them navigate and succeed in college as well as making connections with peers. In some semesters, it was found that student perceptions of their SI student facilitator were a factor in their satisfaction with SI sessions. 

Conclusion:

The outcomes of this study suggest that a peer SI model, integrated with enhanced mindset instruction for target course faculty and peer facilitators, has the potential to improve student academic performance, persistence, and growth mindset. The findings of this study have implications for STEM disciplines and beyond. The process for developing effective, course-specific frameworks for planning SI sessions can be disseminated to other institutions with STEM peer SI or similar programs, as well as being utilized in our institutional SI training programs across all disciplines at the college. The project has contributed to the intellectual merit of the field by demonstrating the effectiveness of an integrated enhanced mindset peer SI model in increasing STEM student and peer SI academic content knowledge, and developing student metacognition, self-efficacy, and growth mindset.


Last Modified: 04/28/2023
Modified by: Clayton F Spencer
